Ecbatana /É›kËˆbÃ¦tÉ™nÉ™/ (Old Persian: ğƒğ¥ğ¶ğ«ğ ğ´ HagmatÄna or HaÅ‹matÄna,[1] literally "the place of gathering" according to Darius the Great's inscription at Bisotun; Persian: Ù‡Ú¯Ù…ØªØ§Ù†Ù‡; Middle Persian: ğ­ ğ­§ğ­¬ğ­²ğ­ ğ­­; Parthian: ğ­€ğ­‡ğ­Œğ­•ğ­ AhmadÄn; Late Babylonian:  
ğ’†³ğ’€€ğ’ƒµğ’‹«ğ’‰¡ á´·áµá´¿Agamtanu Elamite: ğ’€ğ’ˆ ğ’†ªğ’ˆ¾ Agmadana; Imperial Aramaic: ğ¡€ğ¡‡ğ¡Œğ¡•ğ¡€ Aá¸¥mÉ™á¹¯Ä; Ancient Greek: á¼ˆÎ³Î²Î¬Ï„Î±Î½Î± or á¼˜ÎºÎ²Î¬Ï„Î±Î½Î±) was an ancient city and the capital of the Median kingdom.
